When writing a paper or anything, I was wondering whether it was proper english to use a capital G or lowercase, or whether it was either way. I personally think that using G is admitting that it is an actual person or being, which I don't believe. I think that when I write about god it is more of a concept and a beleif so I don't usually capitalize.
 
 My english teacher disagreed with me but after discussing it with me allowed me to write it god. Is it proper english to use the uppercase G?
billsco

How do you refer to Zeus? We aren't making any claim for belief by capitalizing this now-defunct god, only following proper English usage. I agree with your teacher.
 
 I often write critically about the Judeo-Christian god known properly as God. I capitalize the word because I prefer the reader to understand who I'm specifically referring to, and also not allow the non-traditional use of lower case to become an issue in itself. This is often such an inflammatory subject and we should choose our words carefully, if we want the full measure of our message understood. Using the lower case, IMO, is a distraction that causes the eye to stop momentarily upon the word, deciding whether a typo has been committed, and is, it seems, an unnecessary poke in the eye to some Christian readers. 
 
 I would like you to reconsider your decision. Let your words, not your style, be your message.

 I totally disagree with this site.
 
 " Words like atheist, gay, and women are either adjectives or nouns, but are not proper nouns. We should not capitalize them unless they are part of an organization, like Atheist Alliance, or part of an organized movement, collective, or focus of education, like Gay Rights movement or Women's Rights issues or Women's Studies."
 
 I could say the same for Christianity (equivelant to the root ism for Christian). Words like Christianity are either adjectives or nouns, but are not proper nouns. They aren't part of an organization, or part of a movement.
 
 
 "Thus, a person could be a French atheist, an American atheist (any atheist living in America), or an American Atheist (a dues-paying member of a particular organization)."
 
 And a person can be a French christian, an American christian, or an American Christian
 
 
 "Similarly, words like atheism, feminism, and capitalism are not usually capitalized."
 
 Words like christianity, ... are not usually capitalized.
 
 
 "Atheist and religious are states of being, like being rich, poor, educated, etc. When atheist is capitalized it makes it look like the individual subscribes to an organized set of beliefs, like the organized set of beliefs subscribed to by Christians, Buddhists, Muslims, Hindus, etc. However, atheism is not another religion or set of beliefs. It simply denotes the fact that we lack a belief in gods."
 
 Athiest is not a state of being, and I am offended by this. Atheism is a very solid set of beliefs. The beliefs that we do NOT live under a god, and that we should live our lives the way we want to, not for anyone else. Sounds just as much as a belief as believing your life is in someone else's hands.
 
 
 
 Most atheists (not "Atheists") disagree with most religious people (not "Religious" people) regarding the existence of supernatural beings. When we do not capitalize the "a" we have a better defense against the charge that atheism is a religion."
 
 This is simply not true, Athiests and Agnostics are religions and therefor people of those faiths are religious. I'll give a definition of religion and where Atheism fits in at the end.
 
 
 "I can understand the emotional desire to routinely use a capital "a" out of pride. (I used to follow the lead of American Atheists in that regard when I was a member from 1984-90.) However, I now think it is not only grammatically and logically incorrect, but that it tends to make us look a bit insecure."
 
 And you don't think I have a right to be insecure when the government sanctions a national pledge saying we are "under god"?, the money says "in god we trust", we are sworn in on the bible, etc. I was debating on these forums about the pledge and they said we should keep under god because "whether you like it or not, this is a Christian nation". I'm sorry but we have the freedom of religion here in the United States.
 
 Perhaps there was a political and emotional need to use a capital "a" in the 1960's through 1980's, but it strikes me as antiquated now. We have arrived."
 
 That's funny, that's what I think about "under god" in the pledge. We were arguing about how we were better than those "communist non-believers". We don't need to claim we are under god now.
 
 
 I'm only listing the relevant ones. One is about an obsession.
 Religion (Pronunciation) n
 
 1. religion beliefs and worship: people?s beliefs and opinions concerning the existence, nature, and worship of a deity or deities, and divine involvement in the universe and human life
 
 2. personal beliefs or values: a set of strongly-held beliefs, values, and attitudes that somebody lives by 
 Microsoft® Encarta® Reference Library 2003. © 1993-2002 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
 
 
 Atheists and Agnostics fit this category. beliefs and opinions concerning the existence, nature and worship of deity(ies) and diving involvement in the universe and human life.
 
 Either having the opinion that we can't know or not believing is a belief that concerns that. And of course they both are beliefs, values, and attitudes.
 
 Basically they are both religions, I always thought you capitalized Christian and Atheist and Agnostic. But as I have said before, with reference to santa claus, I think it really is the concept of joy and giving just as god is the concept of a supreme life somewhere. With people who believe in god as a being, they should write or type it "God" just as a kid who really believes that Santa Claus is real and will bring him toys.

"Thus, a person could be a French atheist, an American atheist (any atheist living in America), or an American Atheist (a dues-paying member of a particular organization)."

"Similarly, words like atheism, feminism, and capitalism are not usually capitalized."

"Atheist and religious are states of being, like being rich, poor, educated, etc. When atheist is capitalized it makes it look like the individual subscribes to an organized set of beliefs, like the organized set of beliefs subscribed to by Christians, Buddhists, Muslims, Hindus, etc. However, atheism is not another religion or set of beliefs. It simply denotes the fact that we lack a belief in gods."
 
 Athiest is not a state of being, and I am offended by this. Atheism is a very solid set of beliefs. The beliefs that we do NOT live under a god, and that we should live our lives the way we want to, not for anyone else. Sounds just as much as a belief as believing your life is in someone else's hands.

Once something has been established and everyone agrees to it, then maybe yes, but the only thing in common with an atheist is the lack of belief of God or gods....

I think it's a distraction when there is a word capitalized in the middle of a sentence. 
 
 

 
 Yet you're trying to petition that "atheists" be capitalized to be fair? You're morphing your thread into "atheism is a religion".

zachvac

athiest and agnostic are not religions

 
 They both are religions. Allow me to paste the dictionary entry of religion here.
 
 
 religion 
 
 re·li·gion [ri líjjən]
 n 
 1. religion beliefs and worship: people's beliefs and opinions concerning the existence, nature, and worship of a deity or deities, and divine involvement in the universe and human life 
 2. religion particular system: a particular institutionalized or personal system of beliefs and practices relating to the divine 
 3. personal beliefs or values: a set of strongly-held beliefs, values, and attitudes that somebody lives by 
 4. obsession: an object, practice, cause, or activity that somebody is completely devoted to or obsessed by 
 The danger is that you start to make fitness a religion.
 
 5. christianity monk's or nun's life: life as a monk or a nun, especially in the Roman Catholic Church 
 
 
 [12th century. Via Anglo-Norman religiun , from Old French religion , from the Latin stem religion- "obligation, reverence," of uncertain origin: probably formed from religare (see rely).]
 
 
 -re·lig·ion·less, adj 
 get religion to stop flouting the rules, regulations, customs, and expectations of society (informal) to become a believer or join a religious organization, and, usually, start to lead a life that follows its teachings (informal) 
 Microsoft® Encarta® Reference Library 2003. © 1993-2002 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

1, 2, and 3 seem to be the most relevant. 1 obviously is, because someone's beliefs and opinions can be there is no god or there is no possible way of finding out. An institutionalized system of beliefs is basically there is no god or that we can't find out. 3 is the easiest, someone can have a strongly-held belief that there is no god or that we can't find out.
 
 Do you have a different dictionary that gives a different definition? Atheism and Agnosticism both fit in that category.
